awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Health and wellness supportive mobile application
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will be a comprehensive digital lifestyle solution for providers serving patients at low-resourced facilities to optimize patient adherence to diet, physical activity and sleep national guidelines. We define low-resourced facilities as having 10 full time-employees or less, serving patient populations whose median income is at least 25% below the poverty level and are uninsured or under-insured. Patient populations may be characterized as having low health literacy, and experiencing economic and social disadvantage, which are crucial social determinants of health. Thus, the target immediate user, providers at low-resourced facilities, may not have financial, employee, or material resources to support patients to improve their health outcomes. Distal outcomes include improved provider performance measures that could affect reimbursement rates. The commercial impact of a digital support tool is to aid providers in improving the health behaviors of their patient populations that could prevent and manage health conditions in high-need populations.  Providers at low-resourced facilities could supplant their patient lifestyle support services, which typically offer nutrition, exercise, and mental/social support during isolated events.  This mobile application would allow continuous lifestyle support services, outside of patient office visits.

This I-Corps project is focused on a personalized mobile application synced with a wearable device that uses machine learning to generate tailored data visualizations and text messages to optimize user healthful behavior change. Based on customer discovery with providers serving low-resourced facilities, the project aims to unearth whitespace opportunity areas with a novel technical innovation that incorporates three behavioral pillars of cardiovascular health: physical activity, diet/nutrition, and sleep. The proposed application utilizes data on daily lifestyle habits, combined with a user's biological footprint of healthcare data, to automatically generate tailored just-in-time communications to nudge users towards behavior change goals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: New York University School of Medicine

por.por_cntn:
The project outcomes from our I-Corps Health and Wellness supportive mobile application included the culmination of 100 primary interviews with partners, end-users, and potential customers of our digital diabetes self-management platform. We were able to conduct an audience segmentation of customers based on their readiness stage of change(Prochaska's Theory of Change) for adhering to diabetes self-management guidelines based on their level of awareness, knowledge, motivation, self-efficacy and active behavior adoption. Similarly, through the iterative process of talking to providers, such as diabetes educators, nurses, dieticians and endocrinoligist, we were able to identify the "hair on fire" need of the buyer of our solution who was motivated to report improvements on patient diabetes outcomes to increase value-based performance reimbursement levels to payors/health insurance providers. 

Our findings from these primary interviews gleaned two things, 1. a Business Model Canvas to draw insights for our MVP development for future funding; 2. Insights on the motivators for behavior change for people living with diabetes. The two-fold connection between patient and provider was emotionally driven, and clinically based. For instance, for many the cue to action that triggered behavior change was experiencing the pain of a physical condition, that lead to life-altering lifestyle changes. Maintaining that behavior and adhering to clinical guidance was often driven by emotional connection, feeling loved, and the lighht of the human spirit. On the provider - endocrinologist - buyer perspective, the audience segmentation for a1c level improvement for patients living with diabetes could only reach a certain segment of the population. From a diffusion of innovation theory perspective, the laggards and late adopters, were "stuck." Unfortunately, given finite resources, providers will invest but so much to yield an expected return. On the contrary, there was a lot of interest, and current use from diabetes educators, dieticians and nurses using digital platform solutions, that were reporting promising improvements with their patient population.


Last Modified: 11/04/2021
Modified by: Alicia Chung
